bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 17, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses a yellow fever outbreak in Trujillo. He mentions the difficulty of doing prophylactic work in Lima. He offers his opinions regarding a member of the Panama Canal Health Department and the Peruvian government.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 17, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
Contra la Fiebre Amarilla
EN LOS
Departamentos del Norte
----
TRUJILLO
Hanson Sept. 17/21
Trujillo, September 17, 1921.
My Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of May 16, has just been re-
ceived after my arrival in Trujillo on this trip. In this letter
I notice that you had just received the news of the confirma-
tion of the fever in the Province of Trujillo. I thin you will
recall that we had prohesized to these people when we were here
that the fever would reach this Department about April. One of
the Commissarios reminded me of this in June.

The criminal part of this thing was Quiro's obstructiveness
when we wanted to take Mendoza south with us at the time of our
leaving Lambayeque. I think the fever probably would have entered
anyway, but there would have been more of a chance of catching
the first cases in the province of Pacasmayo. I have sent up
the statistical chart on the officially recognized cases in
that Province which shows that the first cases there must have
occured early in March. I am of the opinion that the disease
was introduced after our visit to Pacasmayo and Trujillo. Still
one can not be entirely certain of this. A great many things
have been showing up which I have not yet been able to thoro-
ugly analyze. At times I am very much in doubt about this
pet diagnosis of “fiebre biliosa hemoglobinurica” and have
wondered if it may not be possible that there have been some
endemic foci of yellow fever in this northern section, and the
cases so diagnosed have been cases of yellow fever. Also many
of the diagnoses of “paludismo perniciosa” most likely have
been cases of yellow fever. Why is it that in the zones which
we have cleaned up you never hear of these diagnoses any more
while formerly they were relatively frequent? I have just been
talking to Mendoza about this, and he also is loosing his faith
in the diagnoses of “biliosa hemoglobinurica” and “paludizmo
perniciosa”. This man Don Juliano Arce is still making diagnoses
of this type in Lima, and I have wondered what they are.

In regard to Dr. Tapias work here we corrected that fairly
promptly and eventually got good work started here. Dr. Tapia
has been a very valuable aquisition, seems to have good judge-
ment and is very much interested. He has worked very conscien-
tiously, and kepps his records quite well.

There is not a great deal of need for other physicians, with
Cabellero and Mendoza, I have about all that is needed. The super-
vising Inspectors was the most important addition needed. In so
far as the final outcome is concerned it all depends on the
larvae work, and the extension of the outside zones sufficiently
to prevent anything jumping across. This I believe we are doing
now. Our work in Ancash and the northern section of the Departm-
ent of Lima ought to do this. The employment of Corrigan and
Pickett, even at the high price, was justifiable. They have meant
a great deal to the final outcome of the campaign. I have worked
them and they have worked like very few men ever did work in a
campaign of this kind.

If you think that this work should be continued for any
great length of time, it might be well to send a couple of the
Inspectors to which you refer, to help in the supervision of the
final clean up. I have been thinking about two dates for the
2. H.R.C., September 17, 1921.
final termination of the campaign, January or April. By April
one should know quite definitely what the conditions may be. I
think that if anything is going to show up it should do so before
January, and we ought to find it because it is my plan to keep
up a continuous revision of the entire coast, and cases should
not easily escape us, with such men as Caballero, Mendoza, Tapia
and others continually on the lookout for suspicious cases.
The most uncertain place will be Lima itself, and to do real
prophylactic work there will be very difficult on account of
the interference of the politicians and, Wrightson and Lavoreria.
The last two were very pigheaded about our recommendations in
regard to the quarantine during the Centennial. Dr. White no doubt
will tell you about this. It appears that Lavoreria is running
Wrightson considerably on this point. I shall very probably
have somewhat of an argument with them when I get to Lima. I dont
like their impudence.

In regard to Goldthwaites men, I know very little about them.
I sympathize with them for having been obliged to work with a
man of Goldthwaites type. As far as he is concerned I cant under-
stand what keeps him in the Panama Canal Health Department. I
think he is about the poorest and the most bigoted material I
have ever seen in an important position of that kind. All bluff
and foreflushing.

I know Beverly and Wolcott personally, both good men but I
do not think that either are available. Converse is the man of
the Iquitos fame.

You already know from my other letters and copies what the
Peruvian Government is doing about funds, -which is practically
nothing. I have grown tired of prodding them- it has been so
useless to do so. However I shall make one more attempt when I
get to Lima this time, and then try to leave some definite agre-
ment, by which they fully recognize the International Health
Board as the actual managers of the campaign.

The exchange seems to be improving, and I believe that if
you leave your money for a while you will come out much better,

Our difficulty in the campaign atb present is a general
strike effecting practically the entire Department of Libertad
We are unable to get any transportation, of any kind and are very
much handicapped in our inspections of this Department. In my
letter to Miss Read, copy of which I enclose for your information
you will note what I have written the board about the matter.

I hope the thing will be settled by next week. We need the
railroad facilities to make sure of our conditions.

With the very best wishes, and with many thanks for your
letters and your helpful advise,
